claim: Electronics have become more affordable in the US since 1990.

supporting.text: Advancements in manufacturing technology and economies of scale have significantly reduced the production costs of electronics, leading to lower consumer prices.

attacks.text: Advancements in manufacturing technology and economies of scale have significantly reduced the production costs of electronics, leading to lower consumer prices.
While production costs have decreased, inflation and supply chain disruptions have offset these savings, keeping consumer prices high.
The demand for premium features and brand loyalty have driven up prices despite lower production costs.
Environmental regulations and tariffs on imported electronics components have increased costs, negating the benefits of manufacturing advancements.
Inflation rates have been relatively low compared to the reduction in production costs, so the net effect is still lower consumer prices.
Many consumers opt for budget and mid-range electronics, which have seen significant price drops due to economies of scale.
The long-term benefits of environmental regulations outweigh the short-term cost increases, and tariffs affect only a subset of electronics.
Even with low inflation, the cumulative effect over decades has eroded the purchasing power savings from reduced production costs.
Budget and mid-range electronics often compromise on quality and features, making them less desirable despite lower prices.

supporting.text: The globalization of supply chains has increased competition among manufacturers, driving down prices of electronics in the US market.

attacks.text: The globalization of supply chains has increased competition among manufacturers, driving down prices of electronics in the US market.
Increased competition has led to cost-cutting measures that reduce product quality, offsetting the affordability gains.
Tariffs and trade wars have disrupted global supply chains, increasing costs for electronics in the US.
Currency fluctuations and inflation can negate the price reductions from global competition.
Consumers prioritize price over quality, so reduced quality does not significantly impact affordability perception.
Many manufacturers have absorbed tariff costs rather than passing them fully to consumers.
Inflation-adjusted data still shows a net decrease in electronics prices over time.
Long-term use of low-quality electronics leads to higher replacement costs, reducing overall affordability.
Absorbed costs reduce profit margins, which may limit future investment in innovation.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted prices of many consumer electronics, such as televisions and computers, have consistently decreased since 1990.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted prices of many consumer electronics, such as televisions and computers, have consistently decreased since 1990.
While prices have decreased, hidden costs such as software subscriptions and accessories have increased, offsetting the apparent affordability.
The decrease in prices is primarily for basic models, while high-end electronics have become more expensive, limiting true affordability.
The measure of affordability should include wage stagnation, which means electronics are not more affordable for many low-income households.
Hidden costs like software subscriptions are optional and not necessary for basic functionality, so they don't negate the affordability of the core product.
High-end electronics include advanced features that justify their higher prices, and basic models still meet the needs of most consumers.
Wage stagnation affects all goods, not just electronics, so it doesn't specifically counter the claim about electronics becoming more affordable.
Even optional hidden costs can become necessary over time due to software updates and compatibility requirements, making them unavoidable for many users.
The increasing complexity of basic tasks due to software bloat means that basic models may no longer be sufficient, pushing consumers toward higher-end options.

supporting.text: The introduction of cheaper alternatives from emerging markets has made electronics more accessible to a broader range of consumers in the US.

attacks.text: The introduction of cheaper alternatives from emerging markets has made electronics more accessible to a broader range of consumers in the US.
Cheaper alternatives often compromise on quality, leading to higher long-term costs for consumers due to frequent replacements or repairs.
The influx of cheaper electronics has led to job losses in the US manufacturing sector, offsetting the economic benefits of affordability.
Currency fluctuations and trade tariffs can negate the cost advantages of electronics from emerging markets, making them less affordable over time.
Many consumers prioritize short-term affordability over long-term quality, making cheaper alternatives a viable option despite potential drawbacks.
The US manufacturing sector has shifted focus to high-value electronics, creating higher-paying jobs that compensate for losses in low-end manufacturing.
Stable trade agreements and hedging strategies can mitigate the impact of currency fluctuations and tariffs, preserving affordability.
Frequent replacements of low-quality electronics contribute to environmental waste, undermining the societal benefits of affordability.
The transition to high-value electronics requires specialized skills, leaving many displaced workers unemployed or underemployed.

supporting.text: The rise of e-commerce platforms has increased price transparency and competition, further reducing the cost of electronics for US consumers.

attacks.text: The rise of e-commerce platforms has increased price transparency and competition, further reducing the cost of electronics for US consumers.
E-commerce platforms often add hidden fees such as shipping and handling, which can negate the apparent lower prices of electronics.
The dominance of a few large e-commerce platforms has led to price-fixing and reduced actual competition, limiting cost reductions.
Many consumers lack reliable internet access or digital literacy, preventing them from benefiting from e-commerce price reductions.
Many e-commerce platforms offer free shipping or include fees in the listed price, making the total cost transparent and often lower than physical stores.
Regulatory bodies actively monitor and penalize price-fixing, ensuring that e-commerce competition remains fair and beneficial to consumers.
Initiatives to improve digital literacy and internet access are expanding, gradually reducing the barrier for more consumers to benefit from e-commerce.
Free shipping is often conditional on minimum purchases or membership fees, which can still increase the effective cost for many consumers.
Regulatory actions are slow and often reactive, allowing anti-competitive practices to persist in the short to medium term.

supporting.text: Certain high-end electronics, such as smartphones and premium laptops, have seen price increases due to added features and brand premiums, offsetting overall affordability.

attacks.text: Certain high-end electronics, such as smartphones and premium laptops, have seen price increases due to added features and brand premiums, offsetting overall affordability.
The price increases in high-end electronics are offset by significant price drops in mid-range and budget electronics, making overall electronics more affordable.
The added features in high-end electronics provide greater value per dollar spent, meaning affordability should be measured by utility, not just price.
Inflation-adjusted data shows that even high-end electronics have become more affordable when accounting for general price increases over time.
Mid-range and budget electronics often lack the durability and performance of high-end models, leading to higher long-term costs for consumers.
Utility is subjective and difficult to quantify, making it an unreliable metric for measuring affordability.
Inflation-adjusted data may not account for wage stagnation, which affects consumers' ability to afford high-end electronics despite price trends.
Many mid-range electronics now offer comparable durability and performance to older high-end models, reducing long-term costs.
Consumer satisfaction surveys consistently show that users derive significant utility from high-end electronics, supporting the utility-based affordability argument.
Wage stagnation affects all sectors, not just electronics, so it doesn't negate the relative affordability improvements in the electronics market.

supporting.text: Supply chain disruptions and tariffs on imported electronics components have led to price hikes in some categories, making them less affordable in recent years.

attacks.text: Supply chain disruptions and tariffs on imported electronics components have led to price hikes in some categories, making them less affordable in recent years.
Technological advancements and economies of scale have offset the impact of tariffs and supply chain issues, keeping overall electronics prices affordable.
The price hikes due to tariffs and supply chain issues are temporary and do not reflect the long-term trend of decreasing electronics prices.
The affordability of electronics should be measured by their performance-to-price ratio, which has improved significantly despite recent price hikes.
The benefits of technological advancements are unevenly distributed, with high-end electronics becoming more affordable but budget options seeing significant price increases.
Supply chain disruptions have become more frequent and severe, suggesting that price hikes may persist longer than expected.
The performance-to-price ratio does not account for the basic affordability of electronics for low-income consumers, who are most affected by price hikes.
Even high-end electronics have seen price reductions over the long term, making them accessible to a broader range of consumers despite recent fluctuations.
Companies are adapting to supply chain challenges by diversifying suppliers and investing in local production, which will mitigate future price hikes.
Low-income consumers benefit from the secondary market for electronics, where older models become significantly more affordable as new models are released.

supporting.text: The increasing complexity and demand for cutting-edge technology in electronics have kept prices high for the latest models, limiting affordability for average consumers.

attacks.text: The increasing complexity and demand for cutting-edge technology in electronics have kept prices high for the latest models, limiting affordability for average consumers.
The average price of electronics has decreased over time due to economies of scale and improved manufacturing efficiencies.
Many older models become significantly cheaper as newer versions are released, increasing affordability for budget-conscious consumers.
The secondary market for electronics, including refurbished and used devices, provides affordable options that were not as accessible in 1990.
While economies of scale reduce costs, the rapid pace of technological obsolescence forces consumers to frequently upgrade, offsetting savings.
Older models often lack support and security updates, making them less practical despite their lower prices.
Refurbished and used electronics may have reliability issues, leading to higher long-term costs for consumers.
Technological advancements often bring significant improvements in efficiency and functionality, justifying the cost of upgrades.
Many manufacturers now offer extended support for older models, mitigating the issue of lack of updates.
Certified refurbished programs from reputable sellers often include warranties, reducing the risk of reliability issues.

supporting.text: While base models of electronics have become cheaper, the total cost of ownership (including accessories, subscriptions, and upgrades) has risen, reducing overall affordability.

attacks.text: While base models of electronics have become cheaper, the total cost of ownership (including accessories, subscriptions, and upgrades) has risen, reducing overall affordability.
The rise in total cost of ownership is offset by increased functionality and longevity of modern electronics, making them more cost-effective over time.
Accessories and subscriptions are optional, and many consumers choose not to purchase them, so the base price remains a better indicator of affordability.
The cost of essential accessories (e.g., chargers, cases) has actually decreased, counteracting the argument about rising total ownership costs.
Increased functionality does not necessarily translate to cost-effectiveness if consumers do not utilize all features, leading to wasted expenditure.
Many modern electronics require subscriptions or accessories for basic functionality, making them less optional than claimed.
The decrease in accessory costs is marginal compared to the rising costs of mandatory software updates and cloud services.
Even unused features can provide future-proofing, allowing consumers to delay upgrades and thus save money in the long run.
Consumer choice still dictates spending; many alternatives exist that do not require additional purchases for core functionality.
